title: Ticket #3496: monitor file transfer i/o activity
description:
We propose to have the file transfer queue manager collect monitoring information about i/o activity in the file transfer processes. The quantities to be monitored will be bytes transmitted per second, file read/write load, and network read/write load. By "load" we mean number of file transfer processes performing read/write calls. These quantities will be reported as exponential moving averages over various time scales, by default, 1 minute, 5 minute, 1 hour, and 1 day.

The attached design document contains further details.
remarks:
2013-Mar-05 11:47:24 by johnkn:
It looks to me like time(NULL) is called once for each counter of type stats_entry_sum_ema_rate in the StatisticsPool 

    void AdvanceBy(int cSlots); {
       if (cSlots <= 0);
          return;
       Update(time(NULL));
    }

I don't like how often time is called here. Can't we figure out how to pass time in from higher up the call chain? perhaps define cSlots here as a delta time? (it effectively is a delta time if you know the quantum).

2013-Mar-05 11:59:22 by danb:
Suggestions for how to find out the quantum of time in AdvanceBy()? Perhaps it should be passed into the function?

As for the avoidance of frequent calls to time(), I did some tests under linux and found that it took about 6 nanoseconds per call to time(). If it is similarly cheap under windows, then perhaps it's not worth much optimization. At least the above call to time() is shared by all the moving averages attached to a given metric.

2013-Mar-05 12:33:32 by bbockelm:
Hi Dan,

You don't want to call time() as that is not guaranteed to move forward. You probably want:

clock_gettime(CLOCK_MONOTONIC, ...)

On the upside, it is actually a cheaper call (on newer hosts, this compiles down to reading a processor register).

Brian
